author: sky.cactus
content: This feels like a somewhat arbitrary change, and I think people are trying to understand why delays are being introduced.  There is no additional work being done at the moment that I know of (though there might be work I don't know of!), and everyone is just kind of "waiting for launch".

author: sky.cactus
content: If there really is active work being done, or data being gathered, or tests being run, that needs that extra week I'll be the first to support delaying until August.  I just haven't heard anyone from any of the dev teams state that they will actually do something useful with this extra week.

author: sky.cactus
content: One thing that was mentioned earlier is that there are many people now betting on the release date of London, so there are now financial incentives for both the July and the August launch.  Whichever we choose, we should make sure we have a good reason for choosing it so we can remain "credibly neutral" with our processes.  I'm of the weak opinion that if we have no good reason to delay, then the credibly neutral option is to stick with the originally planned July date.  If we have any good reason to delay, then the credibly neutral thing to do is to delay until August.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is unfortunate that this sort of stuff is necessary (essentially public relations), but I do think there is value in remaining credibly neutral (when possible) in the face of perverse financial incentives.

author: sky.cactus
content: The problem with the current situation is that we have no good reason for the delay, so we are losing that credible neutrality.  People will start shouting that the core devs sandbagged the release date because they bet on August, and those people will do this regardless of whether or not that is true.

author: sky.cactus
content: The same thing I believe would occur if we launched in July despite knowing about some legitimate reason to delay to August.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think it is reasonable to say that "we want 4 weeks after fork block number announced before launch", but that doesn't provide much of an argument for why we didn't set the fork block in the last ACD, or why we didn't follow through with the plan to tentatively pick a fork block number this past Friday after Rinkeby went live.

author: sky.cactus
content: If we wait to pick a block number until after all of the testnets are forked, then it means we always have a month between last testnet and mainnet.  This *feels* excessive to me, as there are notable diminishing returns on "time on testnets".

author: sky.cactus
content: I suppose there is an argument for a release strategy that is "do all the testnets, wait a few days longer, then pick a fork block that is `coordination_time_required` in the future.  ü§î

author: sky.cactus
content: And the delay isn't because we think there are going to be bugs, but because we *don't* think there are going to be bugs (all testnets are running smoothly) and we need `coordination_time_required` weeks in order for the fork itself to go smoothly.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is similar to the old Gold Master idea, where you would cut a release when you were "done writing/debugging all of the code" and then some number of months after that would be your launch date.  This wasn't because you expected to find bugs in those months, but rather because it took time to "deploy" the release in a coordinated fashion (which is desirable).

author: tayvano_
content:
Sorry to jump back to earlier conversation. Here's my (wallet person) perspective on block number for hf:

No wallet or user facing thing has a (valid) excuse for not being ready in July as July has always been the general understanding on when the hf would occur. Most expect things to be a bit slower in reality bc that's how dev things work but, again, core devs being on time not a valid excuse for others lollll.

Imo clients and network security and fuzzing and all that stuff is most important. If they sign off, that's step 1 and probably the only step that's an absolute requirement. 

That said, there are some obvious user facing players where the readiness does have a bigger impact than others. Namely: where the changes being not implemented in time could adversely affect the ecosystem as a whole in a way that would be best for core devs to try to avoid (or at least not blatantly ignore). In this case I would say Etherscan, MetaMask are probably the key ones. Imtoken too as they have vast amt of users in the east. Miners could be considered mostly to at least show some consideration for them where it's easy to do so since there are so many changes occuring that...erhm...don't/can't consider them üòÖ

Lastly, asking "what date do you want" is a v different question than "If any of you has a reason why this date is not viable, speak now or forever hold your peace." I would recommend the latter if asking various players bc the former will not get any form of social consensus. üòâ

Oh and fyi ethcc is July 20-22nd, which only matters if a large amt of key players who need to be on their A game in case things go wrong are attending. I doubt this is the case but....you know.

Doesn't have to, and certainly doesn't have to be a priority when considering dates.

I came up with the named products not by asking if the product would be negatively impacted but rather if the ecosystem as a whole would be and, secondly, if "core devs" would be. Bc were all selfish lol.

I would suspect that if the hf were to be decided to be like tomorrow or something, and a product didnt have time to implenent support for some time after, and ecosystem as a whole would be questioning why. The natural answer is of course "it's the products fault" but, for certain products, very close on it's heels would be "why didn't the core devs take that into consideration when choosing a date."

The only wrong answer is "we didn't consider it." The right answer is "*we discussed it* and agreed [insert literally anything here]."

author: tayvano_
content: Oh and those three products (MetaMask, etherscan, imtoken) were chosen specifically bc 1) huge DAU and 2) lack of realistic alternatives for end users. You can call it a PR move on core devs behalf but it's actually not that. It's avoiding a massive distraction and demoralizing event for those who have have better things to do, should be celebrating the work that went into he fork, and would generally prefer to avoid all "politics." üòâ
